channel.title: Ars Technica
channel.feedburner:browserFriendly: This is an XML content feed. It is intended to be viewed in a newsreader or syndicated to another site.

item.title: Windows Live Local beta nothing to get excited about
item.author: anders@arstechnica.com (Anders Bylund)
item.description: Microsoft rolls out a beta mapping tool to great fanfare. But is it really all sizzle and no steak?

item.title: Lead plaintiff in Nano class action wants out
item.author: arstechnica@bignoisybug.com (Peter Pollack)
item.description: Jason Tomczak, Mac fan, nature lover, and number one name on the class action suit against Apple regarding scratched-up iPod Nanos, wants to separate himself from the case. His reason? He never wanted to be involved in the first place.

item.title: ESA backs Maryland video game sales restrictions
item.author: eric@arstechnica.com (Eric Bangeman)
item.description: The ESA comes out in support of a video game law just passed in Maryland., while a bill banning the sale of violent video games to minors has been withdrawn in another state.

item.title: Net Neutrality: Craig-listing the issue
item.author: caesar@arstechnica.com (Ken Fisher)
item.description: Craigslist founder Craig Newmark takes on a Telecom lobbyist over 'Net Neutrality, while the FCC says that they can step in at any time.

item.title: Senate subcommittee considers ideas for patent reform
item.author: natermailbox-ars@yahoo.com (Nate Anderson)
item.description: Members of the Senate held a hearing yesterday to consider the possibility of post-grant reviews of new patents. Will that be enough to solve the current patent litigation mess?

item.title: StreamCast sues eBay
item.author: natermailbox-ars@yahoo.com (Nate Anderson)
item.description: StreamCast, makers of the Morpheus P2P software, have now added eBay to their "enemies list"—and they want US$4 billion in damages.

item.title: MIT's US$100 laptop prototype completed
item.author: segphault@sbcglobal.net (Ryan Paul)
item.description: A working version of MIT Labs' US$100 laptop for developing countries was shown off yesterday. Is the US$100 laptop dream moving closer to reality?

item.title: Microsoft: Windows Vista is on target, unless it isn't
item.author: caesar@arstechnica.com (Ken Fisher)
item.description: Microsoft is hinting that another Windows Vista delay may be possible, but the focus now is on coordination with partners, not the state of the operating system.

item.title: No Xbox 360 price cuts on the horizon
item.author: eric@arstechnica.com (Eric Bangeman)
item.description: If you were hoping to score a cheap Xbox 360 later this year when the PS3 launches, you'd better think again. Microsoft squashes the 360 price cut rumors.

item.title: TiVo seeks injunction against EchoStar
item.author: natermailbox-ars@yahoo.com (Nate Anderson)
item.description: After winning a patent infringement lawsuit against its rival, TiVo wants EchoStar's DVR service shut down by the court. Oddly enough, both companies claim that the USPTO is on their side.

item.title: Microsoft's Korean antitrust appeal mostly turned down
item.author: anders@arstechnica.com (Anders Bylund)
item.description: Most of Microsoft's appeal of a South Korean antitrust decision has been firmly rejected by the local Fair Trade Commission. It's on to higher courts for the software titan.

item.title: Intel takes wraps off of Woodcrest
item.author: hannibal@arstechnica.com (Jon Hannibal Stokes)
item.description: Intel invites hardware reviewers to benchmark Woodcrest systems, giving a glimpse of things to come in 2006 in the Intel vs. AMD wars.

item.title: Windows, Office betas hit the street
item.author: eric@arstechnica.com (Eric Bangeman)
item.description: Microsoft unleashes betas of Vista, Office, and Longhorn Server at WinHEC. What's new and improved, and who gets to play with the beta software?

item.title: TV networks look to encourage ad-viewing
item.author: arstechnica@bignoisybug.com (Peter Pollack)
item.description: As more and more viewers use DVRs to jump over those darn commercials, TV networks finally look ready to accept the fact that the technology is here to stay. Their new goal: get viewers to watch the ads by adding content to the breaks.

item.title: Microsoft considers removing Admin access for employees
item.author: jeremy@arstechnica.com (Jeremy Reimer)
item.description: Microsoft is considering a change in corporate policy that will see employees move from running as Administrator to using accounts with significantly fewer access privileges. Is such a change necessary?

item.title: Schools block MySpace access; kids fight back
item.author: natermailbox-ars@yahoo.com (Nate Anderson)
item.description: As schools attempt to restrict access to social networking sites, students are finding increasingly creative ways to circumvent the filters.

item.title: New domain launched for mobile phones
item.author: natermailbox-ars@yahoo.com (Nate Anderson)
item.description: The new .mobi domain was designed to make surfing the web easier from mobile devices. Will it work?

item.title: Samsung announces NAND flash PCs
item.author: eric@arstechnica.com (Eric Bangeman)
item.description: A pair of computers coming from Samsung next month do away with the hard drive altogether.

item.title: Global software piracy losses: US$3- or $34-billion?
item.author: natermailbox-ars@yahoo.com (Nate Anderson)
item.description: Piracy is down in China, Russia, and India, but losses are up—to US$34 billion worldwide. That is, if you can believe the numbers.

item.title: AMD launches Socket AM2 processors
item.author: eric@arstechnica.com (Eric Bangeman)
item.description: The Athlon gets support for DDR2 and a few other things. How far will Socket AM2 carry AMD?

item.title: Dell returns to retail, but without the retail sales
item.author: caesar@arstechnica.com (Ken Fisher)
item.description: Watch out mall rats, Dell is coming to a mall near you. But with a strategy that's half retail and half finger crossing, can they expect to capture a significant slice of the competitions retail sales?

item.title: Fantasy baseball case may have First Amendment implications
item.author: arstechnica@bignoisybug.com (Peter Pollack)
item.description: MLB steps up to the plate, hoping to go deep on CDMsports.com's fantasy baseball leagues. At issue? Whether player statistics are owned by MLB or protected under the First Amendment.

item.title: Making money selling music without DRM: the rise of eMusic
item.author: news@arstechnica.com (Ars Technica)
item.description:
We all know who rules the roost when it comes to downloaded music sales. But who's number two? The answer may surprise you.

In the 18 months since the relaunch of eMusic, the company has clawed its way to the number two position among digital download services (this does not include streaming music). Pakman claims that eMusic has 12 percent of the market compared to Apple's 61 percent, and that his company has now sold more than 60 million songs.

Ars looks at eMusic to discover how it has made a thriving business out of selling DRM-free music in an open format.

item.title: ICM sues two state departments, seeking to keep .xxx domain proposal alive
item.author: anders@arstechnica.com (Anders Bylund)
item.description: Now that ICANN has declined to approve the .xxx top level domain (again), ICM Registry is trying to revive the freshly killed initiative (again). I swear, this story is like a zombie movie from the '80s—it just won't die.

item.title: Of denials, state secrets, and network architecture
item.author: hannibal@arstechnica.com (Jon Hannibal Stokes)
item.description: Wired has a blockbuster story on the nuts and bolts of how the government has implemented TIA. Also, I take a look back at last week's denials by Verizon and Bellsouth to see what they do and do not tell us.

item.title: Nintendo, Sony executives heat up flame war
item.author: jeremy@arstechnica.com (Jeremy Reimer)
item.description: As the battle for the next generation of consoles heats up, executives from both Nintendo and Sony are stoking the flames by making increasingly outrageous comments. Will it help their cause, or will too much sniping backfire on everyone?

item.title: Google facing slow uptake on new offerings
item.author: eric@arstechnica.com (Eric Bangeman)
item.description: It seems as though there's a fairly constant flow of new features flowing from Google. What happens when people don't seem to use them?

item.title: Getting a loan from strangers on the Internet
item.author: natermailbox-ars@yahoo.com (Nate Anderson)
item.description: Would you loan money to someone you know only by his Internet profile? Lending website Prosper.com thinks you might.

item.title: Sony BMG balks at EFF legal fees
item.author: natermailbox-ars@yahoo.com (Nate Anderson)
item.description: As the main Sony BMG "rootkit" case draws to a close, the record label and the Electronic Frontier Foundation remain far apart on the issue of money. The EFF wants US$2 million; Sony says US$9,000.

item.title: Microsoft tries pay-as-you-go approach for Windows PCs
item.author: eric@arstechnica.com (Eric Bangeman)
item.description: Microsoft has a novel solution to the problem of the high cost of hardware and software in developing countries. Will it work?

item.title: Hollywood reportedly in agreement to delay forced quality downgrades for Blu-ray, HD DVD
item.author: caesar@arstechnica.com (Ken Fisher)
item.description: An unofficial behind-the-scenes agreement reportedly has Hollywood vowing not to force video quality downgrades on users without HDMI until at least 2010.

item.title: Apple MacBook
item.author: news@arstechnica.com (Ars Technica)
item.description:
With the new MacBook, Apple has completed the transition of its portables to the Intel architecture.

On May 16, the MacBook replaced the nearly seven-year-old iBook and brought with it a new era of consumer-grade portables from Apple. For the first time since the clam-shell style iBooks were discontinued at the beginning of 2001 is an Apple portable available in more than one color. Apple has been toying with the idea of offering both black and white devices since the iPod nano and subsequently the video-capable iPod, and now they've begun offering their consumer-grade portable laptop, the predictably named MacBook, in similar glossy black and white models.

Ars reviews the MacBook to see how it stacks up against its PowerPC predecessor and Apple's other Intel machines.

item.title: Ars System Guide: Gaming Box
item.author: news@arstechnica.com (Ars Technica)
item.description:
The Ars Technica System Guide update for this month is all about gaming. We've got two systems to meet your budget, so if you've been thinking about upgrading, we're here to help.

The Budget Gaming Box falls somewhere between the Budget Box and Hot Rod, as an example of how a little more money goes a long way in graphics and gaming performance. Think of aiming for the 3D performance of the Hot Rod, without the price. The hard drive may not be as big, the case might not be as nice, and the system may not provoke as much geek envy among friends, but the performance is close enough.

The Performance Gaming Box comes in at around double the cost of the Hot Rod and is what the same enthusiast might build if he ahd the budget for a gaming machine that had one sole purpose in life: playing the most demanding games on hardware that that enables a gaming experience with all the bells and whistles turned on. The Performance Gaming Box may share core components with the Budget Gaming Box and other systems from the Ars System Guide, but it is taken to a higher level of performance.

Dive on in and see what's new in the gaming system guide!

item.title: Aperture 1.1 review
item.author: news@arstechnica.com (Ars Technica)
item.description:
It's not every day that we review a .1 update to an application. In the case of Aperture, we thought it was important, and the reasons should be obvious.

By all accounts, the Aperture 1.0 launch bombed. A few loud defenders held their position that Aperture's faults were minor compared to its benefits and its price tag was small for professional photographers, who sneeze 500-dollar bills. I wasn't so convinced. The whole premise of Aperture is that it is to be the hub of downloading, sorting, tagging, rating, commenting, and processing images for output and no amount of PR spin could hide the fact that Aperture failed at being a professional-level RAW processor.

Does version 1.1 fix the many flaws of the initial release? Dave Girard dives in to Aperture 1.1 to see what's new and improved.

item.title: Window management and the power of scripting
item.author: news@arstechnica.com (Ars Technica)
item.description: Linux.Ars returns with some in-depth discussion of window management in general, and Metacity in specific. There's also an update on the new Freespire distro and other tidbits from the world of open source.

item.title: Beatmania
item.author: news@arstechnica.com (Ars Technica)
item.description:
Do you like rhythm games like DDR, Taiko Drum Master, and Guitar Hero? Ars reviews the US release of the title that started it all, Beatmania.

It's odd to think that the first successful rhythm game was a DJ simulator. Not even a DJ simulator really, more like a turntable bolted onto a tiny keyboard/sequencer type of deal. I'm not sure it's even meant to emulate a real musical instrument. While we're used to playing games at the arcade with drums, guitars, and dance mats; the controller for Beatmania is its own beast. A mass of buttons and a turntable: this is what started it all.

If you think you've got rhythm, check out our review and see if Beatmania is for you

item.title: A look at class-action lawsuits
item.author: news@arstechnica.com (Ars Technica)
item.description:
Class-action lawsuits are common, especially when it comes to tech products. iPods, CDs, DVD rentals... you name the product and chances are someone has filed a class-action suit.

There's no denying it: class-action lawsuits feel good. After all, individual consumers have little power over manufacturers, and it's all too easy to see these companies as firms who value only the almighty dollar. Ganging up on, say, the record labels feels pretty good because it gives power to a group of people who otherwise would wield little of it. It balances the asymmetrical power relationship between corporations and consumers.

Ars looks at the phenomenon to determine why they're so common and who ultimately benefits.

item.title: Weathering the storm: explaining a bumpy spring for Apple
item.author: news@arstechnica.com (Ars Technica)
item.description:
Ars takes a look back at three months of turbulence aboard AAPL airlines.

For a couple of years, Apple made all the right moves. From late 2004 onward, Steve Jobs and company rode the iPod and iTMS to ever-higher stock prices. Apple had paid off all its debt in 2003 and the cash was rolling in by the bucket load. Fast forward to January 10, 2006, where we begin our step-by-step inspection. The company reported a massively successful holiday season, iPods were selling as fast as Apple could crank them out, and Jobs unveiled the new Intel-based line of Macs. The stock hit US$85.59 a share on January 13, making the company worth US$72 billion. That was US$2 billion more than Dell at the time. Jim Cramer screamed something about "It's gonna hitUS$100! BUYBUYBUY!" Life was good for the Apple faithful.

What happened? Ars puts 20/20 hindsight to good use and explains why the Apple stock chart looks like a really good roller coaster.

item.title: Tomb Raider: Legend
item.author: news@arstechnica.com (Ars Technica)
item.description:
Everyone's favorite top-heavy videogame vixen is back. Ars checks in on Tomb Raider: Legend to see if developer Crystal Dynamics was able to revive the sagging fortunes of the Tomb Raider franchise.

It takes a leap of faith to play a Tomb Raider game. First, you have to assume that nothing made the ancient people of the world happier than creating gigantic contraptions made of pressure-sensitive switches, huge moving wheels, and hundreds of feet of chains to open the front door of their temples. The titular tombs of the game have to be the most overengineered pieces of architecture you'll ever see. If these guys were living today, we'd have those floating cities we've always dreamed about, I'll tell you that much.

Is this the old Lara Croft we know and love, or another imposter? Read on and find out.

item.title: High-end iPod speaker systems
item.author: news@arstechnica.com (Ars Technica)
item.description:
Apple's iPod Hi-Fi dock and speaker system got a lot of attention when it was announced. We tested it along with two of its competitors, the Klipsch iFi and the Altec Lansing InMotion iM7.

With the growing number of stores carrying the personal audio device and a growing crop of users desiring to hear their music in more places, speaker systems have become an increasingly popular accessory. With the announcement of Apple's foray into high-end iPod accessories, we here at the Orbiting HQ decided to take some of the pricier iPod dockable speaker systems for a spin.

Which speaker system comes out on top? Read on and find out.
